No recycling collection for weeks: PLEASE DO NOT MARK THIS REPORT AS CLOSED UNTIL BINS ARE ACTUALLY EMPTIED.

In spite of multiple reports of missed recycling collections being opened by residents and instantly closed by Lewisham Council, the recycling bins at Meredith Mews are still full as we have had no collection since April. A resident has recently cleaned up all the overflow as it had become a health hazard.

Website says Wednesday is collection day - is that correct?

description:
Scrapyard: Please read properly.

I never directly reported the untaxed vehicles, the category was FLY TIPPING yet you ask me about the vehicles number plates then say no further action. Rude.

The number plates are removed and hidden which is an offence. If you sent someone there you would know that for yourself instead of expecting the public to spoon feed you the information.

There's also a set of metal gates that goes to Phoenix community councils new building site opposite all the guys vans, this has rubbish dumped there also.

You totally ignored the fact that there's oil all over the pavement, car parts scattered everywhere and other automotive fluids due to this persons actions. Would you like to live next door to scrapman so all his rubbish can be outside your house?
title: Scrapyard
detail:

I never directly reported the untaxed vehicles, the category was FLY TIPPING yet you ask me about the vehicles number plates then say no further action. Rude.

This is now my tenth report for these flats, where constantly there is a rubbish on the streets, the wheelie bins are left out and block the pavement, cause rubbish to blow down the street (and Lewisham rubbish collectors have to pick it up), and now there is an armchair and half a sofa in the area where the bins are supposed to be stored. I mean really? Please help as it's now embarrassing. The planning permission was to include the bin storage.

detail:
My recent report on graffiti on buildings and shutters was responded to by Lewisham Council in that if I notified them of a particular building they would try to include that in their programe for cleaning due to not enough funding or staff to take on any large scale cleaning to clear it. It surely needs someone from LBC to look at the state of the High Street and come up with something more positive to clear the problem.

What's happened to the CCTV cameras in the High Street. I'm sure the shop keepers can offer some help, it can't do their business much good trading in such a messy Street. The police must know the tags and the names/addresses of the people causing the damage Shops should not be allowed to sell spray paint or marker pens to under 21's.
title: Graffiti
description:
Graffiti: My recent report on graffiti on buildings and shutters was responded to by Lewisham Council in that if I notified them of a particular building they would try to include that in their programe for cleaning due to not enough funding or staff to take on any large scale cleaning to clear it. It surely needs someone from LBC to look at the state of the High Street and come up with something more positive to clear the problem.

What's happened to the CCTV cameras in the High Street. I'm sure the shop keepers can offer some help, it can't do their business much good trading in such a messy Street. The police must know the tags and the names/addresses of the people causing the damage Shops should not be allowed to sell spray paint or marker pens to under 21's.

detail: This is the third time I have posted about this issue. I do not know why my post is repeatedly removed. There is a huge pile of construction waste dumped on the corner of Billingford Close and Pincott Place, just at the turning off Frendsbury Road. It is a very large mound of excavated earth, bricks, junks of concrete, painted road tarmac, wooden boards, electricity cables, and large white construction waste bags. This is not domestic waste, this is from a construction site.

description: Park Court: Still constant rubbish build up at these flats. Nobody cares - bins always left out on the pavement and not returned to their place and rubbish flies down the road for someone else to pick up. There doesn't seem to be any effort from Lewisham to find out who the landlord is, and therefore the problem just goes on and on. Do we the other residents of the street have to take matters into out own hands?
title: Park Court
detail: Still constant rubbish build up at these flats. Nobody cares - bins always left out on the pavement and not returned to their place and rubbish flies down the road for someone else to pick up. There doesn't seem to be any effort from Lewisham to find out who the landlord is, and therefore the problem just goes on and on. Do we the other residents of the street have to take matters into out own hands?

The crew that just came this morning for collection left the bins out ONCE AGAIN. Why does this continue to happen?! It has been reported tens of times already in the past 6 months, can the right department ease monitor the situation? Can you please now send someone to put everything back to its place, where it was?! Thank you!

description:
Mess at Lewisham Homes property: Hello, An unknown substance has been poured/spilled out of a window belonging to a Lewisham Homes property (flat 5 Stephens Court, 82 Endwell Road). This mess is now down the wall below and over the windows of the two flats below.

Lewisham Homes do not manage the whole of Stephens Court. However, they do rent flat 5 from the owner to provide social housing. Please can you check this as my other report was rejected.

Please can you arrange for someone from Lewisham Homes to attend and clean this up. Thank you.

description: Brick pillar on corner of St Margaret's Square knocked down: Last year a brick pillar on the western corner of St Margaret's Square fell down - perhaps it was hit by a vehicle. Someone has moved it from the middle of the pavement and into the hedge, which is nice, but the smashed up brickwork remains on its side. It's unsightly and needs rebuilding in line with the rules for the conservation area.

description:
Bridge over the River Quaggy: The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.
title: Bridge over the River Quaggy
detail:
The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.

Lewisham’s crews ALWAYS leaving te bins all over the place when they come for collection, instead of putting them back in their dedicated storage. ALWAYS. So every time it’s windy or when something falls off the bins it’s all over in the environment instead of being enclosed. Can someone please come put them back before this yard becomes a dump?! Thank you!
title: Lewisham’s crews doing a sloppy job
description: Lewisham’s crews doing a sloppy job: Lewisham’s crews ALWAYS leaving te bins all over the place when they come for collection, instead of putting them back in their dedicated storage. ALWAYS. So every time it’s windy or when something falls off the bins it’s all over in the environment instead of being enclosed. detail:
For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;
title: Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction
description:
Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction: For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;

title: Overflowing bin because of Lewisham Council incompetence
description:
Overflowing bin because of Lewisham Council incompetence: For over a year the recycle bins in our block, especially the only cardboard bin have been overflowing and residents are forced to throw recyclables in the normal waste bins.

Like previous complaints one bin has been full again for over a week and overflowing for a few days because Lewisham Council continues to fail to deliver this service. Lewisham Council points its finger at Pinnacle and Pinnacle points back and in the interim residents are stuck in the middle of these two corrupt and incompetent organisations having paid for a service which neither provider says it is accountable for.

For over a year the recycle bins in our block, especially the only cardboard bin have been overflowing and residents are forced to throw recyclables in the normal waste bins.

Pigeons have moved into the empty corner shop roof. There is in excess of 30 birds and its increasing. There is large amounts of droppings on the floor surrounding the shop. Pigeon droppings are toxic. They are becoming a nuisance for the surrounding properties too as the population increases.
description: Colony of pigeons in building toxic droppings everywhere: Pigeons have moved into the empty corner shop roof. There is in excess of 30 birds and its increasing. There is large amounts of droppings on the floor surrounding the shop. Pigeon droppings are toxic. They are becoming a nuisance for the surrounding properties too as the population increases.
title: Colony of pigeons in building toxic droppings everywhere

description: Missed recycling collection again and overflowing bins: Our recycling bins were again not collected by Lewisham Council. One bin is full and the two others are at 80-90% because regardless of the missed collection we lack bin capacity. Lewisham Council has been aware of this for over a year but failed to take any action. Neither Lewisham Council or Regenter (Pinnacle) will take responsibility for these ongoing failings which mean 1/4-1/3 of our recylcling has to be placed in normal waste bins. Both Lewisham Council and Pinnacle have stated that the other is responsible and their is no mechanism to hold either to account under the failed Regenter RB3 PFI contract
title: Missed recycling collection again and overflowing bins
detail: Our recycling bins were again not collected by Lewisham Council. One bin is full and the two others are at 80-90% because regardless of the missed collection we lack bin capacity. Neither Lewisham Council or Regenter (Pinnacle) will take responsibility for these ongoing failings which mean 1/4-1/3 of our recylcling has to be placed in normal waste bins. Both Lewisham Council and Pinnacle have stated that the other is responsible and their is no mechanism to hold either to account under the failed Regenter RB3 PFI contract

For over a year Lewisham Council has failed to consistently collect the recycling bins for this Regenter (Pinnacle) managed block. Documented complaints have been made to both but still no action has been taken. Our bins were full before Easter and were not emptied this week so again residents have to use the normal waste bins to dispose of recyclables. Lewisham Council's contractors do not have the capacity to manage and deliver this contract to the required collection frequency and the estate does not have enough bins to cope with increased bin pressures due to COVID behavioural changes. The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.

The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.
title: Recycling bins not collected again

detail: Posting here but nothing will get done about it, council will just mark it 'internal review' which seems to mean ignore it and hope it goes away there has been broken glass on the path into Durham Hill (park) from Mooreside Road for the last week. most has been brushed aside by people kicking it out the way as bigger bits are against the green. like most glass breakages on the roads, the council do sod all about it and leave it up to the public to clean up (Q, where do we send the invoice for this or do we deduct it from the poll tax you just put up?)

Lack of recycle bin capacity
description: Lack of recycle bin capacity: Since April 2020 our blocks ongoing lack of recycling capacity has been exacerbated by COVID. Residents have informed then complained about this to Pinnacle and Lewisham Council. Every week or so our recycling bins are overflowing and residents are forced to place a significant amount of recyclables in the normal waste bins. This has been documented for at least 10 months and the problems still continue but Lewisham Council has wrongly stated that the block has adequate capacity. Our recycling bins have been full for over a week so we continue to waste recyclables. Photo attached.

The concierge at the distillery tower locked the access gate 6 months ago and refuses to open it. My understanding is that this is a public right of way and has to remain opens during daytime hours. I have difficulty in accessing the rear of my building and have to take my bike the opposite way through the building instead of out in to the courtyard and beyond.

title: Access blocked
Dangerous car parking on corner near Co-op
description: Dangerous car parking on corner near Co-op: Cars are parking vertically on the corner of Stanstead Road and Rockbourn Road & obstruct the left view of motorists emerging from Rockbourn Road causing them to get into the centre of the road. Personally had three near accidents at that point because of this. Cars are parked outside the new Co-op so cars heading towards the 205 from Stanstead Road are already overtaking parked cars at that point and meet any vehicle emerging from Rockbourn Road. This issue has been reported to the local Councillor and has been an issue for many months.

This light has been broken for months, but now that it’s so dark, it’s really dangerous in the underpass - you can’t see your footing on the steps and you can see if there’s a mugger hiding in the shadows. It’s really dangerous now!

description:
Large overgrown tree and rusted nails outside 77 Lewisham Way: There is a very large and overgrown tree outside 77 Lewisham Way, which overhangs the pavement and neighbouring property. This tree has never been pruned or inspected and poses a significant potential danger to passers by.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.
title: Large overgrown tree and rusted nails outside 77 Lewisham Way
detail:
There is a very large and overgrown tree outside 77 Lewisham Way, which overhangs the pavement and neighbouring property. This tree has never been pruned or inspected and poses a significant potential danger to passers by.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.

description: Non cutting of grass and privets: The 'green chain walk' in Woodbank Road has not had the grass cut for nearly 3 months. even during lockdown a person with a strimmer or ride on mower could have kept this down. other areas too. green on the corner of Capstone Road and Lame Rock Road also the one in the road with no name between Moorside Road and Capstone Road - opposite the Good Shepard church [PW / Education Facility on your map} both side of the road are very over grown and there has been a tin 'unit' put on there for months. looks like a council thing. also overgrown privets making it impossible to walk on the pavement when cars are also, badly, parked. corner of Moorside Road and Whitefoot Terrace. Corner of Capstone Road and Durham Hill come to mind

Logged 3 years ago and labelled as fixed, but IT IS NOT FIXED. A car crashed into the wall and demolished the brick wall (behind the bins in the photo) and the fence (as visible in the photo). The car nearly killed me walking on the pavement too, and the speed people drive down Brookmill Road is therefore a far larger issue. Don't wait until someone dies to do something. Speed bumps are a must.

description: Developer’s hoarding covered in graffiti: Green Developer’s hoarding on Morden Lane is covered in graffiti, which has now spread to nearby private properties, and wall which is part of a conservation area. Developer is negligent in their maintenance of this; they erected it so should also maintain it in an acceptable condition. Currently it’s damaging the area’s environment and bringing anti-social behaviour/ crime here as a result.

description: Fence already pulled down by gate onto public pavement but now is also pulled entirely away at the other end by the railway. Rubbish being thrown on to Site of Importance for Nature Conservation via this massive hole.: The sections of pulled down fence are huge now and various issues as a result - people can get on to the land and damage/vandalise the scout hut & SINC site all listed with Lewisham as assets of community value. Rubbish being dumped on the site and pathway obstructed with fencing.

Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.
title: Problem not fixed: Stones in Calmont Road
description:
Problem not fixed: Stones in Calmont Road: Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.

detail: The north side of Station Road (by the taxi rank) has overgrown vegetation that has already covered the seating and in encroaching onto the pavement. The area is littered with discarded rubbish (the bins are often overflowing) and has been rat-infested in the past. I'm aware that the area has been baited, in the past.

Shingles on Calmont Road from Hillbrow: The shingles from the un-adopted road Hillbrow Road are deposited onto Calmont Road and are never cleared cleared. This makes this section of Calmont Road uneven and unstable. The other day I was unable to push a pram along this section and had to move to the centre of the road to avoid it which is dangerous to myself and my son.

detail: This pothole has been here for AGES. I reported a long time ago and it’s still not been fixed. It’s actually gotten bigger since I first reporter it and appears to be sinking. It sits next to what appears to be a water mains supply stopcock on the walkway in front of Lewisham Park Towers. It’s close to the front of the Kemsley block building.

description: Lamps out on the footbridge: The lamps along the footbridge next to the park have been out for two years and are a danger as drug addicts and dangerous criminals prey on vulnerable residents. Why has lewisham council ignored all requests for the last two years to have the lamps replaced? A boycott of council taxes is an option if these lamps are not replaced so residents can feel safe when crossing during the dark
